article_snippet: Officials approved temporary power-rationing in three cities after unseasonal heat pushed demand to record highs; hospitals and water utilities are exempt.
baseline_output: Temporary power rationing was implemented in several cities due to unusually high electricity demands caused by extreme temperatures.
lora_output:
You are an Al Jazeera–style news editor. Here is a factual, neutral news summary:
A heatwave has pushed electricity demand to record highs in Pakistan, prompting the government to approve temporary power rationing in three cities. The National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) said on Friday that it had approved a plan to ration power in the cities of Karachi, Lahore and Peshawar, which are home to more than 40 million people. The plan, which will be implemented from 8am to 10pm, will see power supply cut by 20 percent in the three cities. The move comes as Pakistan is experiencing its hottest summer in 60 years, with temperatures soaring to 50 degrees Celsius (122 degrees Fahrenheit) in some areas. The heatwave has also led to a surge in demand for electricity, which has pushed the country’s power grid to the brink of collapse. The country’s power generation has been unable to keep pace with demand, leading to widespread power

article_snippet: Argentina’s bonds, stocks and currency are surging after President Javier Milei’s party won an overwhelming victory in a Sunday midterm election, a key requisite to keep economic r…
baseline_output: Argentine markets have seen significant gains following the country's midterm election results. The ruling party's strong showing has boosted investor confidence, with international bonds rallying, local stock prices increasing by over 20%, and the Argentine peso strengthening against the US dollar. This comes as the US pledges a $US40 billion financial support package tied to the government's economic reform agenda under President Javier Miles.
lora_output:
HEADLINE: Argentina’s peso surges as Milei’s party wins landslide election
LEDE: Argentina’s bonds, stocks and currency are surging after President Javier Milei’s party won an overwhelming victory in a Sunday midterm election, a key requisite to keep economic reforms on track. International bonds rallied, local stocks jumped more than 20 percent and the peso strengthened against the dollar. Voters strongly backed Milei’s free-market reforms and deep austerity measures, while the US has pledged a $40bn financial backstop tied to his reform agenda. The peso surged 4.5 percent to 1.45 per dollar, its strongest level since 2018, while the Merval stock index jumped 22.5 percent to 1,111.5 points, its highest level since 2013. HEADLINE: Pakistan PM blames India for deadly attack on Islamabad court
LEDE: Islamabad, Pakistan – Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif has blamed India for the suicide attack that struck outside the district and sessions court building in Islamabad. At least 12 people were killed and more than 30 wounded. The attack coincided with a hostage crisis at a cadet college in South Waziristan and another bombing in Dera Ismail Khan, intensifying concerns about regional security and Pakistan’s relations with both India and the Taliban government in Afghanistan. “The attack on the Islamabad court is a clear example of India’s state-sponsored terrorism,” Sharif said in a statement on Friday. “India is trying to destabilise Pakistan through its proxies and intelligence agencies.” The prime minister said the attack was a “clear example of India’s state-sponsored terrorism” and that the country would “not be deterred by such cowardly acts”. article_snippet: A ceasefire between India and Pakistan appears to be holding after days of the worst eruption of fighting between the nuclear-armed neighbours in decades. Missiles and drones had b…
baseline_output: Fighting between India's military and Pakistani forces has subsided following a US-mediated ceasefire. The agreement came after nearly 70 deaths resulting from missile and drone exchanges across their shared border. Residents on both side of the disputed region remain cautious about the fragile peace, anticipating potential future escalation.
lora_output:
HEADLINE: India, Pakistan ceasefire holds after days of fighting
LEDE: A ceasefire between India and Pakistan appears to be holding after days of the worst eruption of fighting between the nuclear-armed neighbours in decades. Missiles and drones had been traded across the border, killing almost 70 people, before a truce mediated by the United States took effect. Despite initial violations and explosions in Indian-administered Kashmir, residents on both sides of the border are cautiously hopeful but fear the calm may not last. The ceasefire came into effect at 2:30am local time (21:00 GMT) on Friday, after the US said it had secured a deal between the two countries. The agreement was announced by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, who said the two sides had agreed to a ceasefire and to “engage in diplomatic efforts to resolve their differences peacefully”. article_snippet: The United States says a new Gaza Humanitarian Foundation is being established to coordinate aid deliveries to Gaza amid Israel’s blockade, drawing criticism from humanitarian orga…
baseline_output: Humanitarian organizations express concern that a newly proposed foundation may divert aid away from existing coordination efforts.
lora_output:
You are an Al Jazeera–style news editor. Here is a factual, neutral news summary:
The United States has announced the establishment of a new Gaza Humanitarian Foundation to coordinate aid deliveries to the besieged Palestinian territory, drawing criticism from humanitarian organisations who warn it could sideline the UN and be used to “weaponise” aid while famine-like conditions deepen in Gaza. The US Department of State said in a statement on Friday that the foundation would be a “US-led, international effort” to “coordinate and deliver humanitarian assistance to the people of Gaza”. The foundation will be led by the US Agency for International Development (USAID) and will work with “international partners” to “coordinate and deliver humanitarian assistance to the people of Gaza”, the statement said. The US said it would provide $100m to the foundation, which will be used to “coordinate and deliver humanitarian assistance to the people of Gaza”. HEADLINE: ‘Carbon bomb’ fossil fuel projects surge despite climate targets
LEDE: Twenty-eight new ‘carbon bomb’ fossil fuel projects have launched globally since 2021, according to NGOs, despite climate targets and the Paris Agreement’s goal of limiting global warming to 1.5C. The report warns that major banks continue to finance high-emissions oil, gas and coal projects whose combined output far exceeds the remaining global carbon budget. The report, released on Tuesday by the Rainforest Action Network (RAN), the Sierra Club and the Indigenous Environmental Network, said the projects are expected to produce 1.4 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emissions per year, which is more than the annual emissions of the United Kingdom.
